data.title: Windows: problems with symlinks with GIT scm

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.11.0-insider (bc9a7bb1f90557c271c39628b5a3cdd7dfbc750c, 2017-03-30T08:11:58.005Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.15063
- Extensions: 

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|typings-installer|benjaminromano|0.2.0|
|vscode-eslint|dbaeumer|1.2.8|
|theme-dracula|dracula-theme|1.8.0|
|tslint|eg2|0.8.1|
|vscode-great-icons|emmanuelbeziat|1.1.44|
|Theme-azure|gerane|0.0.2|
|docthis|joelday|0.4.3|
|theme-material-theme|jprestidge|1.0.1|
|vs-color-picker|lihui|0.6.0|
|Theme-MaterialKit|ms-vscode|0.1.1|
|debugger-for-chrome|msjsdiag|2.7.0|
|view-in-browser|qinjia|0.0.5|
|java|redhat|0.0.13|
|ActiveFileInStatusBar|RoscoP|1.0.2|
|vscode-hexdump|slevesque|1.2.1|
|eval|Stormspirit|0.0.6|
|omnipascal|Wosi|0.13.0|;


---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open a VSCode in a new workspace
2. In this workspace, create a directory symbolic link (in an admin terminal: ```mklink /D shared c:\```)
3. Open or create .gitignore file and add a new entry for "shared" and save

What happens:
In the git panel, "shared" appears in the list of changes with a "file" icon as if it was a file. Btw clicking on it does switch to the files panel but doesn't select the "shared" simlink.

What should happen?
"shared" should not appear in the changes list.

As you can see: typing "git status" in a command prompt doesn't show "shared" in the list of changes:

![gitproblemsymwindows](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/199648/24515247/4af78860-1577-11e7-8e4c-edb8b4df23f1.png)

data.title: "text/x-code-output" not working for Output panel colorization
data.body:
In VS Code version 1.10.2, it looks like the output panel is ignoring colorization for the mime type "text/x-code-output".  I can't tell if this is a bug, or no longer supported.  

This is what is used by the ["Output Colorizer"](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=IBM.output-colorizer) extension.  

I can't seem to get the "text/x-code-output" mime type to correctly display colorized text in the output panel, but I am able to colorize other mime types and files with specific extensions.   I can still see that the "text/x-code-output" mime type is still being used [here](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/aca643ec36da0f253793268a6ff301dc92e3df11/src/vs/workbench/parts/output/common/output.ts#L20).

data.title: TypeScript code lenses: Mention required TypeScript version in settings
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.11.0-insider (bc9a7bb1f90557c271c39628b5a3cdd7dfbc750c, 2017-03-30T08:05:51.645Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 15.6.0

Following up on a discussion about #20832: The settings for reference and implementation code lenses should mention what the lowest required version of TypeScript is for them to work (2.0.6 and 2.2.0 from what I see).

data.title: Support navigateUp/Down between Open Editors and file tree in Explorer
data.body:
- VSCode Version: `1.11.0-insider`
- OS Version: `Mac OS 10.12.4`

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Focus within a file in an editor, with the Explorer open to the left. 
2. Use a keybinding to trigger `navigateLeft` to move focus to the Explorer. If the focus is moved to the file tree you cannot `navigateUp` to access the Open Editors section. If the focus is moved to the Open Editors section, you cannot `navigateDown` to the file tree.

data.title: Go to definition of default import
data.body:
I'm not sure if it's TypeScript issue or VS Code issue.
When directly importing the default of a module - 
Go to definition of a reference of the imported object goes to the import line and not to the module (then clicking Go to definition again goes to the module file).

Explicitly setting an alias is giving the expected behaviour. 

![](https://media.giphy.com/media/l4FGylPFatd8M2Jvq/giphy.gif)

- VSCode Version: 1.10.2
- OS Version: OSX 10.11.6

data.title: Git statusbar widgets stay visible when git isn't the active scm provider
Scroll markdown preview with editor scroll
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.10.2
- OS Version: macOS 10.12.3

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Begin editing a markdown file
2. Open side by side markdown preview
3. Scroll editor window

There are two settings for scrolling under markdown:
- markdown.preview.scrollPreviewWithEditorSelection
- markdown.preview.scrollEditorWithPreview

It makes sense to also have a setting to scroll the preview window when the editor is scrolled. I always find myself scrolling the editor window expecting the preview to scroll with it.

data.title: Debugger doesn't stop inside Bluebird Promises or Generators
[loc][Query][VSCode] Please clarify meaning
data.body:
Hi, we have a question from a translator. Could you help please?

**Source:**
A problem pattern or the name of a contributed or predefined problem pattern. Can be omitted if base is specified.

**File Name:**
src\vs\platform\markers\common\problemMatcher.nls.resx

**Resource ID:**
".resx", 0; "PatternTypeSchema.description"

**Query:**
Could we understand "base" as "base problem pattern"? Please confirm. Thanks!

data.title: Trim whitespace at the end of each line when pasting text
data.body:
**VSCode Version:** 1.10.2
**OS Version:** 10.12.3

Text that contains white spaces at the end of each line messes with the indentation. My suggestion is to always trim the whitespace when pasting text or make it an option.

**Steps to Reproduce:**

1. Copy the following text to clipboard:
```ruby
describe file('path') do                                                        
  it { should exist }                                                           
  it { should be_file }                                                         
  it { should be_readable }                                                     
  it { should be_writable }                                                     
  it { should be_owned_by 'root' }                                              
  its('mode') { should cmp '0644' }                                             
end
```

2. Notice the white spaces at the end of each line. Try to ident the first line.

![2017-03-30 15 29 10_fixed](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1868454/24509868/758cf05a-155f-11e7-9d1a-788122db10e5.gif)

data.title: Weird syntax highlight of TypeScript function return type when array
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.10.2
- OS Version: Windows 10 Pro (64 bit) [Microsoft Windows [Version 10.0.14393]]
- TypeScript Version: 2.2.1

**Steps to Reproduce**

1. Create new TypeScript file
2. Write a new class
3. Add property using "prop" snippet with some name and type `any[]`

**Result**

The syntax highlight of the property type is shown as in screenshot below

**Expected result**

The brackets of the array type should be highlighted in white as well. (I'm using the default color scheme)

---

**Screenshot**

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7047377/24507213/2c23d626-1560-11e7-984e-82ffdf70bfe0.png)

---

EDIT: Also just found this to be the case on function normal function return types, even when there is a union return type
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7047377/24507751/9eded584-1561-11e7-939f-77e09e70791a.png)

- VSCode Version: 1.10.2
- OS Version: Windows 8.1 x64

Steps to Reproduce:

Don't know how to reproduce and what are the factors that make it happen. Restarting the IDE helps, but the issue keep being reproduced from time to time. Maybe I may provide some sort of dumps or telemetry?

data.title: "JavaScript heap out of memory" when building on RHEL-7
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.10.2
- OS Version: RHEL-7 (7.3 with nightly packages on the way towards 7.4).
- NodeJS: v6.9.4 (packaged in the EPEL-7 repository)
- NPM: 3.10.10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Try to build RPM package using https://gitlab.com/mcepl/vscode-pkg/blob/master/vscode.spec
2. Observe the failure

The [build log](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/files/881940/build.log.txt) ends with:
```
<--- Last few GCs --->
  208718 ms: Mark-sweep 1158.0 (1436.2) -> 1158.0 (1436.2) MB, 1781.4 / 0.0 ms [allocation failure] [scavenge might not succeed].
  210553 ms: Mark-sweep 1158.0 (1436.2) -> 1158.0 (1436.2) MB, 1834.4 / 0.0 ms [allocation failure] [scavenge might not succeed].
  212438 ms: Mark-sweep 1158.1 (1436.2) -> 1158.0 (1436.2) MB, 1885.3 / 0.0 ms [allocation failure] [scavenge might not succeed].
<--- JS stacktrace --->
Cannot get stack trace in GC.
FATAL ERROR: MarkCompactCollector: semi-space copy, fallback in old gen Allocation failed - JavaScript heap out of memory
 1: node::Abort() [gulp]
 2: 0x109b1dc [gulp]
 3: v8::Utils::ReportApiFailure(char const*, char const*) [gulp]
 4: v8::internal::V8::FatalProcessOutOfMemory(char const*, bool) [gulp]
 5: v8::internal::MarkCompactCollector::EvacuateNewSpaceVisitor::Visit(v8::internal::HeapObject*) [gulp]
 6: v8::internal::MarkCompactCollector::VisitLiveObjects(v8::internal::MemoryChunk*, v8::internal::MarkCompactCollector::HeapObjectVisitor*, v8::internal::MarkCompactCollector::IterationMode) [gulp]
 7: v8::internal::PageParallelJob<v8::internal::EvacuationJobTraits>::Task::RunInternal() [gulp]
 8: v8::internal::MarkCompactCollector::EvacuatePagesInParallel() [gulp]
 9: v8::internal::MarkCompactCollector::EvacuateNewSpaceAndCandidates() [gulp]
10: v8::internal::MarkCompactCollector::CollectGarbage() [gulp]
11: v8::internal::Heap::MarkCompact() [gulp]
12: v8::internal::Heap::PerformGarbageCollection(v8::internal::GarbageCollector, v8::GCCallbackFlags) [gulp]
13: v8::internal::Heap::CollectGarbage(v8::internal::GarbageCollector, char const*, char const*, v8::GCCallbackFlags) [gulp]
14: v8::internal::Factory::NewFillerObject(int, bool, v8::internal::AllocationSpace) [gulp]
15: v8::internal::Runtime_AllocateInTargetSpace(int, v8::internal::Object**, v8::internal::Isolate*) [gulp]
16: 0x1a493cd079a7
```
The local computer has 4GB free memory (12GB total), 3+GB free disk space on ``/home`` partition.

ini file with unmatched quotes stops highlighting

---

2. See highlighting

data.title: Allow different sort orders in Source Control view
data.body:
When I try to stage a number of untracked git files, the UI is not displaying the changes correctly. Normally the staged changes will be listed at the top, but recently they are displayed within the middle of the regular changes, and scrolling produces strange UI effects (e.g. the title "STAGED CHANGES" disappears when scrolling)

![vscodeprob](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/16581685/24498369/98fa4d10-153e-11e7-8015-cd6c552803d7.jpg)
![buggy_view](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/16581685/24498374/9b542c84-153e-11e7-8622-d41a07e81bda.jpg)


- VSCode Version:1.10.2 
- OS Version: macOS Sierra 10.12.3

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Add a bunch of untracked git files to be staged

data.title: Markdown preview breaks when moving the markdown file
data.body:
Whilst editing a markdown with the preview (side-by-side), moving the markdown file caused the preview to lock, so further updates to the markdown file are no longer reflected in the preview. Moving the markdown file back to the original location allows the preview to work again.

- VSCode Version: 1.10.2
- OS Version: Windows 10 x64 Build 10586.839

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open markdown file
2. Ctrl+K V
3. Move file to subfolder
4. Begin modifying the markdown file
5. Observe that changes are not reflected

data.title: Feature Request: change CodeLens position in the editor to make loading smoother
data.body:
Hello,

CodeLens is a superb feature. But right now, in its current implementation, I think it's almost unusable. :(

Because CodeLens are lazily added to the editor, they break the code structure. You open the editor, then the lines "jump", and then CodeLens appear. This is not great: my eyes look at something, then everything move. It's jarring. And it can take a bit of time before they appear if the codebase is large enough.

And it happens every time a file is opened.

Moreover, even if CodeLens were not lazily added, the problem would still be here: the code structure changes because of CodeLens, and my file is visually different because of that.

That's why I think that putting CodeLens above a line is wrong.

Possible solutions:

- The CodeLens are placed at the right of the line, instead of above (instead of using the word "References", an icon could lighten the interface a bit, too).
- Add a marker near the line number on the left.

Quick mockup:

![codelens](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/478621/24495131/8134f5cc-1534-11e7-9fcd-5d45b4796376.png)

Thanks for considering this. :)
